Graphical abstract The 1,6-conjugate hydrogenation of para-quinone methides to diaryl- and triarylmethanes under atmospheric pressure has been proposed and accomplished. In the presence of [Cp*Ir(2,2′-bpyO)(H2O)] (0.5 mol %), a range of desirable products were obtained in high yields. Functional groups in bpy ligand were found to be crucially important for the catalytic activity of iridium complexes. Furthermore, the practical application of the present catalytic system was also presented. Keywords Para-quinone methides Atmospheric pressure 1, 6-hydrogenation Qiarylmethanes Triarylmethanes Metal-ligand bifunctional catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Phenol-containing diaryl- and triarylmethanes represent an important class of scaffolds widely distributed in naturally occurring products and other biologically active compounds. For example, they were used as antioxidant prototype (A, Avrainvilleol) [1a], thyroid hormone analogue (B) [1b], anti-tubercular agent (C) [1c], HIV-1 integrase inhibitor (D) [1d], nonsteroidal estrogen receptor agonist/antagonist (E, Lasofoxifene) [1e] and human pancreatic cancer PANC-1 cell inhibitor (F, Muchimangin) [1f] (Scheme 1 ). They were also frequently utilized as key intermediates for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals and functional materials [2]. Given the importance of phenol-containing diaryl- and triarylmethanes, several methods for the synthesis of such compounds have been developed over past few decades. The classical Friedel–Crafts alkylation [3] and direct C–H functionalization [4] of phenols suffer from the use of stoichiometric amount of strong Lewis acid (e.g. AlCl3 or FeCl3), tedious multi-step reactions for the preparation of diazo compounds, site-selectivity and multi-alkylation problem. Transition metal-catalyzed cross-couplings of organometallic or boronic reagents with aryl halides have emerged as a powerful approach to the preparation of such compounds [5]. However, these procedures still suffer from the high toxicity of aryl halides, multi-step reaction (the protection and deprotection of active phenolic hydroxyl group) and low atom efficiency. In recent decade, para-quinone methides (p-QMs), having both carbonyl and olefinic moieties in same structural skeleton, have exhibited unique chemical reactivity as precursor of phenols and has attracted considerable attention [6]. In particular, they were utilized as acceptors in 1,6-nucleophilic conjugate addition reactions for the construction of structurally diverse molecules [7]. Several groups have also demonstrated the 1,6-conjugate reduction of para-quinone methides to diaryl- and triarylmethanes catalyzed by B(C6F5)3 [8], Cu(OAc)2 [9] and UO2(NO3)2·6H2O [10]. Despite highly effective, these procedures required high catalyst loading (5–10 mol %), the excess amount of expensive reducting agents (2–4 equiv of Hantzsch ester, Ph2SiH2 or Et3SiH) and produced a large amount of waste. From the standpoint of sustainable chemistry, the development of a new catalytic system for the synthesis of diaryl- and triarylmethanes from para-quinone methides with high atom economy under environmentally benign conditions is highly desirable. Fujita, Yamaguchi et al. have synthesized a range of Cp*Ir complexes bearing an a bipyridonate ligand or α −hydroxybipyridine, exhibiting the unique catalytic activity for acceptorless dehydrogenation of N-heterocycles and alcohols [11], and the production of hydrogen gas from an alcohol-water solution based on the concept of ligand-promoted dehydrogenation [12]. We have also reported that such complexes are effective metal–ligand bifunctional catalysts for acceptorless dehydrogenation [13] hydrogenation [14], hydrogen (or deuterium) autotransfer process [15] and developed a series of new type of metal–ligand bifunctional catalysts [16]. As part of our continuing interest in this field, we wish to describe our effort toward 1,6-conjugate hydrogenation of para-quinone methides to phenol-containing diaryl- and triarylmethanes under atmospheric pressure. Furthermore, the practical application of the present catalytic system was presented. 2 Result and discussion To explore the feasibility of above proposal, a range of Cp*Ir complexes were chosen as catalysts for the 1,6-conjugate hydrogenation of 4-(4-chlorobenzylidene)-2,6-di-tert- butylcyclohexa-2,5-dienone (1a). In the presence of cat. 1–8 (0.5 mol % Ir), the hydrogenaion of 1a proceeded in tert-amyl alcohol at 80 °C under atmospheric pressure for 12 h to give the product 2a in ≤ 10 % yield (Table 1 , entries 1–8). When Cp*Ir complexes bearing an α,α’-dihydroxybipyridine ligand [Cp*Ir(6,6′-(OH)2–2,2′-bpy)(H2O)][OTf]2 (cat. 9) or a bipyridonate ligand [Cp*Ir(2,2′-bpyO)(H2O)] (cat. 10) was used as the catalyst, the product 2a could be obtained in 97 % and > 99 % yields, respectively, indicating that functional groups on bpy ligand are crucial for the catalytic activity of iridium complexes (Table 1, entries 9–10). Cp*Ir complexes bearing a 2,2′-bibenzimidazole ligand [Cp*Ir(BiBzImH2)Cl][Cl] (cat. 11) or 2,2′-methylenebibenzimidazole ligand [Cp*Ir(2,2′-CH2BiBzImH2)Cl][Cl] (cat. 12) did not exhibit catalytic activity for this transformation (Table 1, entries 11–12). Then, cat. 10 was selected as the catalyst for further examination. When the reaction temperature drops to 70 °C and 60 °C, the product 2a were obtained in 90 % and 82 % yields, respectively (Table 1, entries 13–14). Using THF, 1,4-dioxane or toluene as a solvent, the hydrogenation afforded also the product 2a in > 99 % yield (Table 1, entries 15–17). Having established the optimized conditions (Table 1, entry 10), 1,6-conjugate hydrogenation of a range of para-quinone methides to diarymethanes was investigated and these results are shown in Table 2 . Similar to the case of 1a, reactions of para-quinone methides bearing one or two halogen atoms, such as chloride, dichloride, fluoride and bromide, afforded corresponding products 2b-2e in 90–96 % yields. Stronger electron-withdrawing substituents, such as trifluoromethyl and trifluoromethoxy groups, were tolerated as well and desired products 2f and 2 g could be obtained in 81 % and 90 % yields, respectively. When substrates bearing one or two electron-donating substituents, such as methyl, dimethyl, ethyl, isopropyl, tert-butyl and methoxy groups were utilized, desired products 2 h-2n were obtained in 89–96 % yields. For phenyl-, naphthyl- and thiophenyl-substituted para-quinone methides, reactions gave corresponding products 2o-2q in 87–96 % yields. Furthermore, the catalytic system is compatible with para-quinone methides bearing other substituents on ortho-position of OH group, desired products 2r and 2 s were obtained in 95 % and 97 % yields, respectively. As shown in Table 3 , the 1,6-conjugate hydrogenation of para-quinone methides to triarylmethanes was examined. The reaction of 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-(diphenylmethylene)cyclohexa- 2,5-dienone proceeded smoothly to give the desired product 4a in 97 % yield. When substrates bearing an electron-donating or electron-withdrawing substituent on a benzyl ring were served, corresponding products 4b-4f could be obtained in 80–96 % yields. A plausible mechanism is proposed for the hydrogenation of para-quinone methides to phenol-containing diaryl- and triarylmethanes catalyzed by cat. 9 or cat. 10 (Scheme 2 ). Initially, an unsaturated species A was formed through the elimination of HOTf and H2O from cat. 9 or H2O from cat. 10. The bipyridonate ligand accepted a proton in the step of the activation of H2 to give iridium hydride species B. Accomplished by ligand-promoted simultaneous transfer of the hydride on the iridium and the proton of OH on ligand to α,β-unsaturated carbonyl group of para-quinone methides, catalytic species A was regenerated and phenol-containing diaryl- or triarylmethanes were released as desired products [17]. As outlined in Scheme 3 , the practical application of the present catalytic system was presented. Under established conditions (Table 1, entry 10), the gram-scale 1,6-conjugate hydrogenation of 1a (1.65 g, 5 mmol) afforded the product 2a in 95 % yield. In the presence of AlCl3 (5 equiv), the de-tert-butylation of 2a was carried out at room temperature for 4 h to give the key intermediate 5 in 80 % yield [8] which could be further converted to target products 6 (hypoglycemic agents) [18] and 7 (leukotriene A4 hydrolase inhibitor) [19] according to a previous reports. 3 Conclusions We have demonstrated the first example of 1,6-conjugate hydrogenation of para-quinone methides to diaryl- and triarylmethanes under atmospheric pressure. In the presence of [Cp*Ir(2,2-bpyO)(H2O)] (0.5 mol %), a series of desired products were obtained in high yields. The method is attractive due to 100 % atom efficiency and environmental friendliness. Functional groups in bpy ligand were found to be crucially important for the catalytic activity of iridium complexes. Furthermore, the practical application of the present catalytic system were also presented. Notably, the research exhibited new potential of metal–ligand bifunctional catalysts for green organic synthesis. 4 Experimental section 4.1 General experimental details High-resolution mass spectra (HRMS) were obtained on a HPLC-Q-TOF-MS (Micro) spectrometer and are reported as m/z (relative intensity). Accurate masses are reported for the molecular ion [M + H]+. Melting points were measured on a X-6 micro-melting apparatus. Proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra were recorded at 500 MHz. Chemical shifts are reported in delta (δ) units, parts per million (ppm) downfield from tetramethylsilane or ppm relative to the center of the singlet at 7.26 ppm for CDCl3. Coupling constants J values are reported in Hertz (Hz), and the splitting patterns were designated as follows: s, singlet; d, doublet; t, triplet; q, quartet; m, multiplet; br s, broad singlet. Carbon-13 nuclear magnetic resonance (13C NMR) spectra were recorded at 125 MHz. Chemical shifts are reported in delta (δ) units, ppm relative to the center of the triplet at 77.0 ppm for CDCl3. 13C NMR spectra were routinely run with broadband decoupling. Analytical thin-layer chromatography (TLC) was carried out using 0.2 mm commercial silica gel plates. coredata.dc:description: The 1,6-conjugate hydrogenation of para-quinone methides to diaryl- and triarylmethanes under atmospheric pressure has been proposed and accomplished. In the presence of [Cp*Ir(2,2′-bpyO)(H2O)] (0.5 mol %), a range of desirable products were obtained in high yields. Functional groups in bpy ligand were found to be crucially important for the catalytic activity of iridium complexes. Furthermore, the practical application of the present catalytic system was also presented.
